  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29226].
  {panel}


Roger Symonds
27 Jul (10 days ago)

to Josh 
Hi Josh, 

Hope you're doing well!

Quick note, it would be great if JIRA had a default "Home" directory set and configured. In the wizard this could be checked with the user and if a custom home directory was provided, update the config AND add a symbolic link in the default home directory which points to the custom home directory.
* Makes it much easier to spin up a new instance of JIRA (for new admins, evaluators, etc. don't need to configure a home directory - just use the default)
* Provides a standard place for the home directory (easier to support, more predictable - allows creation of help scripts etc.)
* If a custom home directory is provided it's still easy for an Admin to see where it is (from the symbolic link in the standard home directory)
I like the new drop down over the JIRA logo (to allow for switching instances), this will help with federation later, and usability (easy for users to find the other Atlassian products, they feel more connected/associated/related and consistent). 
Sounds a little like this issue raised in December '08: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-13976  :-)

Cheers,
Roger

Roger Symonds

CustomWare | Sydney, Australia | www.customware.net | roger@customware.net
Australia: +61 2 9900 5733 | Mobile: +61 421 556 995 | Skype: roger.symonds | Twitter: rogersymonds

Connect Salesforce.com and Atlassian Confluence with CustomWare - http://ow.ly/crFgn

-----------
Josh Devenny jdevenny@atlassian.com
11:03 (7 hours ago)

to me 
Hey Rog,

Thanks for the suggestion! I do agree with you that this would be rather helpful for those installing JIRA, however our focus at the moment is on project-administration, as well as viewing/editing issues.

Have you raised a ticket on JAC for this? Just so we can track it when we eventually get back to working on the installers.

Cheers
Josh

Hi team

 The JIRA Charting plugin uses the custom field *[CHART] Time in status* to collect and render the data for time in status charts. However, if a new custom field with the same type is created, the plugin stops working properly.

 Also, the plugin's documentation refers to *Time in Status* field (without [CHART]), which can be "invoking" the users to create it manually, reproducing the issue.

Regards,

Paulo Renato

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29213].
  {panel}

Starting JIRA 5.1, the embedded crowd has been upgraded from version 2.3.2 to 2.4. This includes the security fix [CWD-2690] (won't be visible to public) that has been announced in Crowd 2.3.6 release notes - [Crowd 2.3.6 Release Notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Crowd+2.3.6+Release+Notes].

In JIRA, this has caused a lot of issues to customers with SSL-ed LDAP integration. Mainly because JIRA used to not verify that the server's SSL certificate is valid for the host name in the LDAP connection URL.

In Crowd, one can still have the old behaviour by workarounding it:
{quote}
As a workaround for deployments where there is an expected difference, using an 'ldaps' connection URL and leaving 'Secure SSL' unchecked will preserve the previous behaviour and make an SSL connection but will not verify that the hostname and certificate match.
{quote}

However, in JIRA, once you enable "Use SSL", there is no way we can fallback to the old behaviour like Crowd above.
!SSL_UserDirectory.png!

This feature request is to propose to have similar config/option like Crowd to allow an SSL LDAP connection but without verifying that the hostname and certificate match (fix of CWD-2690).

h5. Workaround options

# Fix the certificate to contain the correct name. This is the preferred (and most secure) fix.
# Edit /etc/hosts on the LDAP server to allow you to use the incorrect name in the certificate. Add the FQDN on the certificate and match it to the IP address of the server.
# (!) Backup Confluence database beforehand for safety purpose
#- Run the following SQL query:
{code}
UPDATE cwd_directory_attribute
SET attribute_value='false'
WHERE attribute_name='ldap.secure'
AND directory_id  = <desired_directory_ID>;
{code} 
#- Restart JIRA
#- (i) *Note*: The above option will always reverted to its default ('true') whenever you edit the user directory settings. Therefore, you'll need to run that query every time you do any changes on the user directory settings.
fields.summary: Add an option in User Directory settings to make an SSL LDAP connection but without verifying that the hostname and certificate match

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29204].
  {panel}

The *Date Time* custom field does not comply to the rules of configuration of "Date/Time Formats" from the Look and Feel. Kindly refer to the attached screenshots.

*Example*: Complete Date/Time Format 	dd/MMM/yy HH:mm

*Workaround prior to 4.4* 
# Shutdown JIRA instance
# Create the *jira-config.properties* in your {{JIRA Home Directory}}
# Insert the following into the file (example: dd/MMM/yy HH:mm) or other format that you want to have
{code}
jira.date.picker.javascript.format = %e/%b/%y
jira.date.time.picker.javascript.format = %e/%b/%y %H:%M
jira.date.time.picker.java.format = dd/MMM/yy HH:mm
jira.date.picker.java.format = dd/MMM/yy
{code}
# Delete the contents of {{JIRA Installation Directory\work}} directory
# Restart JIRA instance

*Workaround 4.4 and later*
# Go to _General Configuration > Advanced_
# Configure the format as below
{code}
jira.date.picker.javascript.format=%e/%b/%y
jira.date.time.picker.javascript.format=%e/%b/%y %H:%M
jira.date.time.picker.java.format=dd/MMM/yy HH:mm
jira.date.picker.java.format=dd/MMM/yy
{code}
fields.summary: Custom Field "Date Time" is not following the format on the "Date/Time Formats"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29202].
  {panel}

When LDAP users are deleted in the LDAP server JIRA will automatically delete the users on JIRA side during the next synchronization.

This behavior would cause a known issue which is documented on knowledge base article here:

* [Issues associated to users deleted from LDAP or crowd can not be reassociated to a different user|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Issues+associated+to+users+deleted+from+LDAP+or+crowd+can+not+be+reassociated+to+a+different+user]

It would be great if JIRA would be able to do the following scenarios:

*Option 1*
# User deleted on LDAP server
# JIRA synchronize with LDAP server and understand that there are missing users
# JIRA check if the users have created any content on JIRA
# If the users have created any content JIRA would keep the users and deactivate it for licensing purposes

*Option 1*
# User deleted on LDAP server
# JIRA synchronize with LDAP server and understand that there are missing users
# JIRA check if the users have created any content on JIRA
# JIRA deleted the user on LDAP directory
# Re-create the user in "Internal Directory"
# Deactivate it for licensing purposes
fields.summary: JIRA Should Handle Deleted LDAP User(s) Better

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29200].
  {panel}

This error message appears often, in JIRA logs:

{panel}
Method getHtml threw exception for reference $column in template templates/jira/issue/table/issuetable-issue.vm
{panel}

This message is a symptom, not a root cause, from what I can tell. Here's what I found:

# I think [this is the best description of it|https://github.com/garyhodgson/tinymce-renderer-plugin/issues/30]:
bq.  If my search result contiains and issue for which myField is null/empty, then I get an error in the Jira search, as well as an exception in my Jira log. If modify my entry to have a non-Null/blank field in myField, then the Entry Navigator works as expected, with no errors returned.
# Looking through [SAC tickets|https://support.atlassian.com/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa?reset=true&jqlQuery=summary+~+%22%5C%22Method+getHtml+threw+exception+for+reference%5C%22%22+OR+description+~+%22%5C%22Method+getHtml+threw+exception+for+reference%5C%22%22+OR+comment+~+%22%5C%22Method+getHtml+threw+exception+for+reference%5C%22%22+ORDER+BY+created+DESC] (*note*: these are not public), we have what would appear to be 45 different root causes, including NPEs, Illegal Argument exceptions, GreenHopper Rank exceptions, even OutOfMemory Errors. They apply to all different custom field types. 

*Improvement Request*
In general I'm thinking this is an innocuous error, given that the true root cause is what error message appears below it (the NPE or otherwise), but perhaps it's worth implementing better error handling to indicate which custom field has the problem, and for which issue ID. This error is spamming the logs and is quite common.

*Workaround*
If you're a customer and are seeing this issue in your environment, look at the stacktrace error below this one to identify a true root cause.
fields.summary: Handle 'Method getHtml threw exception for reference $column in template templates/jira/issue/table/issuetable-issue.vm' errors more gracefully

When JIRA does not have enough permission to read its own {{crowd.properties}} it will return the following stack trace:

{code}Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: org.apache.commons.httpclient.URIException: URI-Reference required

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29194].
  {panel}

Let me explain the situation first.

We have clients speaking different languages, so ideally they should see the login page in their own language, not the system's default locale. But since we also have a much larger user base poorly understanding English, we're keeping our system locale set to Russian, and that confuses our English-speaking clients.
What we need right now is the ability to over-ride default language for only the login page without touching the system locale, with, say a parameter (login.jsp?lang=en). Is that even possible with the current release of JIRA?

Another possible way would be to automatically detect users' locale based on browser settings.
fields.summary: Please add the ability to override language of the login page (or browser-based locale detection)

  {panel}

Upon project import, if a customfield has an invalid context please throw a better exception or perhaps even just ignore the field entirely and show a warning (since it doesn't have a valid context it doesn't show up anywhere and thus can't have any data).

Andreas Knecht has offered the following ideas on this:
{quote}
I think the BackupOverBuilderImpl.getCustomFieldConfigurations() method could have a try catch or something for this problem and then print the appropriate warning.
{quote}

The reason for this is currently if an import is done with a field invalid context an NPE is thrown giving no more information about the problem.

Current error:
{code}
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.jira.imports.project.core.BackupOverviewBuilderImpl.getIssueTypesList(BackupOverviewBuilderImpl.java:282)
	at com.atlassian.jira.imports.project.core.BackupOverviewBuilderImpl.getCustomFieldConfigurations(BackupOverviewBuilderImpl.java:220)
	at com.atlassian.jira.imports.project.core.BackupOverviewBuilderImpl.getProjects(BackupOverviewBuilderImpl.java:187)

	at com.atlassian.jira.imports.project.handler.BackupOverviewHandler.getBackupOverview(BackupOverviewHandler.java:28)
	at com.atlassian.jira.imports.project.DefaultProjectImportManager.getBackupOverview(DefaultProjectImportManager.java:190)
	at com.atlassian.jira.bc.imports.project.DefaultProjectImportService.getBackupOverview(DefaultProjectImportService.java:180)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.importer.project.ProjectImportSelectBackup$BackupOverviewCallable.call(ProjectImportSelectBackup.java:236)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.importer.project.ProjectImportSelectBackup$BackupOverviewCallable.call(ProjectImportSelectBackup.java:224)
	at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl$TaskCallableDecorator.call(TaskManagerImpl.java:358)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask$Sync.innerRun(FutureTask.java:303)
{code}

Crowd Embedded doesn't currently synchronise a user's primary group, as per the attached screenshot. It looks like this is because it's not a {{memberOf}} object, as in the sample LDIF below:

{noformat}

{noformat}

Can you please improve the Embedded Crowd engine in JIRA so that it imports the primary group of the user? Thanks!

h5. Workaround

Set up the User Directory so that it uses the [Default Group Membership|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+to+an+LDAP+Directory#ConnectingtoanLDAPDirectory-AddingUserstoGroupsAutomatically] functionality. This will require a permission setting of Read Only, with Local Groups. This won't bring over the Primary Group, however it will let you set a default group for *all* users.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29180].
  {panel}

We need some kind of advise regarding the JIRA Structure plugin, e.g. is this future safe solution? It seems to fill a significant functional gap so why did'nt Atlassian make such a function in the first place? This Igor Sereda (who seems to be an extremely bright guy by the way), does he run a one man show? If so, do we dare to go that way, is that really future safe??? (our products have a very long life cycle!!!)
 
We have several JIRA projects representing both the delivery product level and (often common) sub-products on various levels. For a few projects we use GreenHopper since long and now we tink that Rapid Board seems to be one way to start using Greenhopper for more products as we can span over several JIRA projects that way.

But some people here are interested in the Structure plugin and such a choice seems me - to some extent - be an alternative to use Rapidboard.

So I really need some kind of product road map though I know that that is not in line with the policy of Atlassian.

Or could we get some kind of statement from Atlassian regarding the future of the Structure plugin or the functionality it represents?

Please!!
fields.summary: Is the JIRA Structure Plugin consistenet with JIRA medium or long time product planning.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29161].
  {panel}

Idea taken from here [https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=154633652]

Support often takes data from customers where there's still a bit of overhead and time involved in getting the data from the customer to a working state in support.

What currently happends:
* Support needs to convince customers that our [data anonymizer|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=154633652] is safe enough for them to trust (it really isn't)
* Customer follows that guide (sometimes with difficulty, needing more bounces) and attaches the backup
* Support needs to restore the backup locally
** Turn off emailing
** Worry about CDATA cleaning
** Change the passwords to sphere
** Change any cwd_directory info disabling everything but local directory
** Worry about any remote groups and make them local groups also 
* Then we can log in and start troubleshooting

*Request*
It would be great if JIRA BTF's internal backup facility could just do this, use joost.jar to anonymise a backup on request and send it off to a support issue all in one go - just tick a box "anomonize backup for Atlassian support" and there it is.
fields.summary: Put the support backup Anonymizer into JIRA BTF

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29159].
  {panel}

It's been found that the Heatmap on the wallboard while filtering on project labels shows entirely different results compared to the project summary screen label Heatmap. 

Note the screenshot, the top browser is the heat map gadget filtering on labels in a project, the word *Corel* is the only large label, then the bottom browser is on the project summary page, note the varying sizes of the labels.

It's been found that the code that produces the algorithm of these two heatmaps is entirely different hence the sizes of the text being rendered inconsistently. Please make these consistent, possibly relying on the project summary algorithm/code over the dashbaord's.

This issue is particularly visible in Projects with multiple Issues where labels (or another value used in the Heatmap) weren't used until a big number of Issues has been created.
fields.summary: JIRA Heatmap gadget code inconsistent algorithm between wallboard and project summary

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29154].
  {panel}

If proper configuration and documentation is done, an administrator should never be locked out of their JIRA instance's web interface. The reality is that mistakes happen and this is actually a fairly common scenario.

The common workaround to this problem is to use the steps mentioned here: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Retrieving+the+JIRA+Administrator

This is a fairly complicated process, and is dangerous because it requires direct database modifications. Additionally, enterprise organizations may have a separate JIRA administrator and database administrator. This results in a longer, drawn out, access and modification request process. 

Google Analytics shows 10,323 page views (see image) for the above mentioned document in the last year alone. A search on SAC for the document brings up 310 support tickets (I am not saying it was absolutely useful in each ticket, just what came up in a search for the url). This procedure is also frequently used internally by support engineers when dealing with customer data.

In other products I have worked on, there has been an easy to use backdoor feature. 

It is important for the backdoor to natively verify a certain level of access permissions before it is triggered. 

I propose that we add a parameter to the jira-config.properties file along the lines of:
{code}
jira.backdoor = 0
{code}

To enable, you would simply set it to 1, and restart the JIRA instance.

This would be read at the time of JIRA starting and would disable all authentication directories within JIRA, and attach a single directory with a preconfigured user and password. This directory would not be editable (or can be generated at boot time, so modifications do not persist). 

By placing this option in the configuration file, we are verifying that:

# The user has access to the server running the instance
# The user's level of access allows them to write changes to the jira-config.properties file
# The user's level of access allows them to restart services / applications

This would also serve as a first step towards providing a solution to JRA-1924
fields.summary: Backdoor administrative access via configuration files

  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 4 January 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Filtering for active and inactive users has been available in Atlassian Cloud for some time.

We do not expect that we will re-implement this feature for JIRA Server at any point in the future, therefore we have made the decision to close this issue.

If you are using JIRA Server right now, there are a couple options:
# You can use the JIRA REST API to return active users, inactive users, or both using the {{/rest/api/2/user/search}} resource and the {{includeActive}} and {{includeInactive}} query paratmers
# You can query the JIRA database directly [as described here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Search+for+Inactive+Users]
 
I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.
 
Regards,
Dave Meyer
dmeyer@atlassian.com
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

*Original request description (original description was blank, so let's use one of the duplicates' description for clarity):*
I suggest to add another combo box to Filter Users section, which allows filtering the list by users' statuses (all/active/inactive).
fields.summary: Filter out inactive users in the Users list

I want that the Remaining Estimate column in "Issue Navigator" shows the value depending of the subtasks, too; equals to when you are in dispform and you click in "Include subtasks".

Anyway, the remaining estimate on the Issue Navigator is only able to display the Remaining Estimate from the parent issue without including the ones from the sub-tasks.

Example: 

Parent task - Remaining Estimate: 3w
 Subtask - Remaining Estimate: 1w 1d

Displayed on Remaining of Parent task View Screen / dispform after ticking the "Include Subtasks": 4w 1d

Displayed on the Issue Navigator: 3w

What should be displayed: 4w 1d

When using the Windows Installer, it does not set the {{%JAVA_HOME%}} system variable. h5. To workaround

Set the {{%JAVA_HOME%}} as in [setting JAVA_HOME|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Installing+Java#InstallingJava-2SettingJAVAHOME].

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29103].
  {panel}

We get quite a large number of support cases where customers are asking for the steps to take to upgrade from a 3.x instance to our latest version. I usually bounce the following information, however it seems like we should add it to our documentation. I would normally provide them with the following:

{quote}
Prior to upgrading, it's recommended to review the [Production Releases|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Production+Releases] page. If you take a look at all the major release notes it will provide a list of all the new features you'll receive as part of the various upgrades. Please take a look at the [Supported Platforms|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Supported+Platforms] page for 5.x, particularly the browser support. We recommend Chrome or Firefox to access JIRA, however if you are restricted to Internet Explorer within your organisation please ensure that your users will have access to IE8 at the minimum prior to upgrading. If possible, using IE9 would be preferred.

To upgrade from JIRA 3.x to 5.x, you would need to do this upgrade in two steps. First 3.x to 4.4.5 and then 4.4.5 to 5.x - it's done this way as 5.x is only backwards compatible up to JIRA 4.0.x. To upgrade, please follow the below version specific documentation

* 3.x to 4.4.5: [Migrating JIRA to Another Server|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA044/Migrating+JIRA+to+Another+Server].
* 4.4.5 to 5.x: [Migrating JIRA to Another Server|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA050/Migrating+JIRA+to+Another+Server].

(i) There is a lot of important information in these guides, please ensure everything is followed.

As advised in the [Backing Up|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA044/Migrating+JIRA+to+Another+Server#MigratingJIRAtoAnotherServer-2BackingUpr] section you will need to transfer the database contents (via XML), the home directory and the attachments to the new server.  I imagine you will want to do a fair amount of testing on the new version - depending on how long this takes you may need to transfer the information twice, due to changes in the production database between the time the backup was made and the time testing was completed.

One of the *most important* tasks to do during the upgrade will be [migrating the existing JIRA configuration over to the new one|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA044/Migrating+JIRA+to+Another+Server#MigratingJIRAtoAnotherServer-34MigrateyourexistingJIRAconfigurationsovertoyournewJIRAinstallation] when upgrading between 3.x and 4.4.5. This is particularly important, especially if you have any custom configurations in JIRA or you're using integration with Active Directory. As of JIRA 4.3, Crowd has been integrated into JIRA, enabling synchronisation with Active Directory/LDAP servers a lot easier. Please have a look at our [Configuring User Directories|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA044/Configuring+User+Directories] documentation if you're using LDAP/AD.

If you have any customisations to JIRA or internally developed plugins, it's recommended to get JIRA up and running successfully prior to installing any additional plugins or making customisations. As discussed in the migration guide, please ensure to check your plugins are compatible with the new version. As part of JIRA 4.3 there is also a [New Plugin Management System|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA044/JIRA+4.3+Release+Notes#JIRA43ReleaseNotes-NewPluginManagementSystem] and any customised plugins may have to be set up manually, depending on what version they are.

One common error is that when upgrading, some of your plugins may not be compatible with the new version of JIRA and this will generate some errors. If this does happen, please disable those plugins, or remove them from {{$JIRA_HOME/plugins/installed-plugins}} and install them through the [Universal Plugin Manager|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Managing+JIRA?+Plugins#ManagingJIRAsPlugins-InstallingaJIRAPlugin] after you have performed the initial upgrade.
{quote}

Can you please add a page to CAC that has some information on big upgrades, such as 3.x to 5.x? Thanks :)
fields.summary: Add documentation for large upgrades - e.g.: 3.x to 5.x

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29096].
  {panel}

We are using JIRA as an e-mail conversation logger.

A client sends to an address and an issue is created. 

A team is informed of the new e-mail (special velocity template makes it look like a "pure" e-mail from the client - Only the Subject is restricted by JIRA)

All replies from any of the team to the client gets logged and the entire team is informed on comments or updates (one is generated if there is no attachment and the 2nd is generated in case of attachment).

We have changed the velocity files of issuecommented.vm and issueupdated.vm so as to resemble a "pure" e-mail correspondence.

The entire team get all updates and comments, so all members of the team can follow the e-mail conversation between us and the client.

However: Attachments are stored in the ticket and is not forwarded as a notification.

Here is the relevant velocity extract for issuecreated:
#if ( $issue.getProject().getString("key") == "<OUR PROJECT>" )
$!issue.description
#if ($attachments && $attachments.size() >0)
$i18n.getText("template.attachments"): #foreach ($attachment in $attachments)$attachment.getFilename()#if ($velocityCount != $attachments.size()), #end#end
#end

And the e-mail looks like
====
<e-mail text>

Attachments: <attachment name>
====

The attachment goes into the JIRA ticket and all team members need to log in to look at the attachment. 

And if a team member sends an attachment to the client, it gets stripped off and stored in the JIRA ticket and does not reach the client.

My question: Are you looking into making sure there is a way in the velocity file to actually attach the file and make sure the e-mail correspondence is totally transparent in case a correct velocity file is made?

I know that velocity file hacking is not part of your support, but in case it is only a one-liner in the velocity file (text preferably) I would be grateful for this line... ;-) 

Your Client,
  Staffan Ohlsson
  European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, Grenoble France
fields.summary: Allowing JIRA to work as an e-mail exchange logger

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 4 January 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days.

We've made the decision to close this request. We are focused on improving usability across JIRA – inline editing issues is an important part of JIRA feeling fast and fluid. We would prefer to concentrate our efforts on making the click-to-edit interactions faster, smoother, and more consistent across all areas of the project. Furthermore, adding feature-level behavior configuration on a per-user basis adds significantly more complexity to JIRA and slows down the product for everyone.
 
I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.
 
Regards,
Dave Meyer
dmeyer@atlassian.com
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

I just recently noticed the new feature called "Click to edit". While I understand the need to quickly edit a field, I have two problems with this feature:

# Any click on any part of the text triggers this feature. Some people (like me) click on text to select and de-select it (mabye to copy it, or to just make it easier to follow the text while reading), or just to get the focus on the right window. People who do this will most likely end up in edit mode unwantingly (like I have done maybe 10-15 times already today).
# The feature is only configurable on a global level, when each user should be able to configure it individually.

My suggestions is this:

* Make this configuration possible per user.
* Give three configuration options:
*# Full "Click to edit" functionality (as it works now)
*# "Click to edit" using the upper right icon, while any click on the body text does nothing (This one would be my personal favorite)
*# Completely disable "Click to edit"

I don't know what "Affects Version" to select, since we use Jira OnDemand or what's it called.
fields.summary: Feature "Click to edit" should be configurable per user, and in three variations

We have set up a "Number Field" named "turnover" which is only present for the "Requirement" issue type.

If you now start searching for e.g. "{{updated > '-2d'}}" and include the "turnover" column, you get the message "Note: Not all the fields below are shown in Issue Navigator for each issue (eg custom fields which are only per-project and/or per-issue type).".

What this actually means is, that the field "turnover" will not be included in any view (like "Excel (All fields)"), even for the issues which have this field.

Also in the meantime something like "Note: If a field is not available to all queried issues, it will not be shown in Issue Navigator (eg custom fields which are only per-project and/or per-issue type)." would be a more appropriate warning in my opinion.

*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29069].
{panel}
h4. +Summary+

Currently "/rest/api/latest/user/search" API does not return all users if search string is *blank*:
 * /rest/api/latest/user/search?username=

h4. +Notes+

In various environments, it has been observed that setting username to one of the following characters will do the trick:
 * /rest/api/latest/user/search?username="" (double quotes)
 * /rest/api/latest/user/search?username='' (single quotes)
 * /rest/api/latest/user/search?username=. (dot)
 * /rest/api/latest/user/search?username=% (percent)
 * /rest/api/latest/user/search?username=_ (underscore)

Also, *maxResults* and *startAt* seem to be functioning.

(/) For example, in JIRA 7.3, the following calls will return 5 users starting from the 3rd user in the list:
 * [http://localhost:8730/jira/rest/api/latest/user/search?username=""&maxResults=5&startAt=2|http://localhost:8730/jira/rest/api/latest/user/search?username=%22%22&maxResults=5&startAt=2]
 * [http://localhost:8730/jira/rest/api/latest/user/search?username=''&maxResults=5&startAt=2|http://localhost:8730/jira/rest/api/latest/user/search?username=%27%27&maxResults=5&startAt=2]
 * [http://localhost:8730/jira/rest/api/latest/user/search?username=.&maxResults=5&startAt=2]

(i) Replace [http://localhost:8730/jira] with actual Base URL

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-29059].
  {panel}

The ATR creates 1 velocity engine per plugin. Each one of these has a fixed-size pool of 20 parsers that end up using a lot of memory.

We should try to reduce this. One option is to plug in a different pool implementation for the parser pools (they are pluggable).

The holy grail would be to reuse 1 Velocity engine across all plugins (actually, one for velocity 1.5 and another for 1.6). Don't know if this is possible but it should be!

To go back to the old behaviour on 5.1.x, pass -Datr.velocity.fixed.size.pool=true as a JVM system property
